statement.title: Problem Description
statement.content: On the way to the next secret treasure hiding place, the mathematician discovered a cave unknown to the map. The mathematician entered the cave because it is there. Somewhere deep in the cave, she found a treasure chest with a combination lock and some numbers on it. After quite a research, the mathematician found out that the correct combination to the lock would be obtained by calculating how many ways are there to pick $m$ different apples among $n$ of them and modulo it with $M$. $M$ is the product of several different primes.

statement.title: Input
statement.content:
On the first line there is an integer $T (T \leq 20)$ representing the number of test cases.

Each test case starts with three integers $n, m, k (1 \leq m \leq n \leq 10^{18}, 1 \leq k \leq 10)$ on a line where $k$ is the number of primes. Following on the next line are $k$ different primes $p_1, . . . , p_k$. It is guaranteed that $M = p_1 · p_2 · · · p_k ≤ 10^{18}$ and $p_i \leq 10^5$ for every $i ∈ \{1, . . . , k\}$.

statement.title: Output
statement.content: For each test case output the correct combination on a line.
